div.p: I think probably when I lost my dad I think that was a massive change in my life; I was able to get the opportunity to go out
to Jamaica on a youth exchange where Prince Charles paid for 15 of us to go out to Jamaica so when I came back from Jamaica
I brought some photos back and I went to Bristol, St Paul’s where my dad’s from and I went into his... well I thought he lived
in a flat but when I got there it was a bedsit and it was probably about from the side of that wall there to about here
and I walked in there and he had a car seat as a settee, he had a picture of Haile Selassie who’s the Jamaican god
and he had a little table, he had a little single bed, he had a black and white TV and I just knew he wasn’t living a conscious life.
We sat there and we spoke and I was drug dealing at the time but I thought I’m not going to tell you that. As I went to leave
he said to me “oh can you go and get me something from the kitchen cupboard” and he had this little box
and I went to go and get it and came back and he opened it up and he gave me a bag of 2ps in a money bag, it was about
£1.60 in there, bless him, and I was like “oh thank you dad” I didn’t want to say “what am I going to do with that? I’ve got £300-£400 in my pocket in notes"
but I thought I couldn’t tell him that so I left it at that and as I went to leave the house and he gave
me the money bag he grabbed my hand and he said “God’s speaking to me at this moment” and I said “what do you mean?”
he said “you’re not living a righteous life” and I said “what do you mean dad?” and he said “you know what I mean”
he said “you know where I am” and I was like “yeah alright” and as I went to leave and he grabbed me and he said
“do you know what? There’s one thing I want you to become, is a leader not a follower” and I was like “yeah, yeah alright dad, alright”
in one ear and out the other and unfortunately I think it was 4 months later I had a phone call from my mum to say that
my dad had collapsed in the bookies in Bristol and he, yeah he passed away 10 minutes after the phone call so I went to go and see him
in the chapel of rest in Bristol and I asked my mum if I could have 10 minutes with him alone and as my mum walked out and I shut the chapel door
it was like these speakers just came on and all I could hear was my dad saying “be a leader not a follower, be a leader not a follower”
and I just broke down crying and that was it and I gave up everything, everything and again I’d done every drug apart from heroin
through my time of drugs and that so I thank my dad every day for giving me this opportunity because I think if it weren’t for the loss
of my dad I don’t think I’d be where I am now I think I’d probably be either behind bars or maybe possibly in a body bag myself...
